title-group.article-title: Preservation of Viscoelastic Properties of Rabbit Vocal Folds after Implantation of Hyaluronic Acid-Based Biomaterials

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Otorhinolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, Inha University School of Medicine, Incheon, Korea
2School of Chemical & Biological Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, Korea
3Department of Communication Sciences & Disorders, Iowa University, Iowa City, Iowa, USA
4Department of Pathology, Inha University School of Medicine, Incheon, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Jae-Yol Lim, MD, Department of Otorhinolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, Inha University School of Medicine, 3-Ga Shinheung-dong, Jung-Gu, Incheon 400-711, Korea Email: jylim@inha.ac.kr

fn.p: These authors contributed equally to this article.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: To compare the rheological characteristics of structurally different hyaluronic acid (HA)-based biomaterials that are presently used for phonosurgery and to investigate their influence on the viscoelastic properties of vocal folds after implantation in an in vivo rabbit model.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: In vitro and in vivo rheometric investigation.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Experimental laboratory, Inha and Seoul National Universities.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Viscoelastic shear properties of 3 HA-based biomaterials (Rofilan, Restylane, and Reviderm) were measured with a strain-controlled rheometer. These biomaterials were injected into the deep layers of rabbit vocal folds, and viscoelastic moduli of the injected vocal folds were determined 2 months after the injection. The vocal fold specimens were observed using a light microscope and a transmission electron microscope.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All HA-based biomaterials showed similar levels of shear viscosity, which were slightly higher than that of human vocal folds reported in previous studies. Compared with noninjected control vocal folds, there were no significant differences in the magnitudes of both elastic shear modulus (G’) and viscous modulus (G”) of injected vocal folds among all of the materials. Light microscopic images showed that all materials were observed in the deep layers of vocal folds and electron scanning images revealed that injected HA particles were homogeneously distributed in regions of collagenous fibers.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: HA-based biomaterials could preserve the viscoelastic properties of the vocal folds, when they were injected into vocal folds in an in vivo rabbit model. However, further studies on the influence of the biomaterials on the viscoelasticity of human vocal folds in ECM surroundings are still needed.

body.p: The viscoelastic properties of vocal folds are directly related to phonation threshold pressure, which is defined as the minimum subglottic pressure required to initiate and sustain vocal fold oscillation. Accordingly, optimal tissue viscosity needs to be maintained to facilitate phonation with the least vocal effort. The elasticity of vocal folds is important for the control of a fundamental frequency, and optimal tissue elasticity is necessary for voice production at higher fundamental frequencies.1

The extracellular matrix (ECM) of most tissues contains a high concentration of hyaluronic acid (HA), which serves various important functions including mechanical stabilization, lubrication, shock absorption, and cell-biological functions in wound healing.2 HA is a nonsulfated glycosaminoglycan and has extensive molecular interactions to remain highly entangled and hydrated in the ECM. Chan et al found that HA plays an important role in determining the viscoelastic properties of the vocal folds.1

Since Hallen et al reported that HA was biocompatible and durable up to 6 to 12 months when used as a bioimplant for phonosurgery,3 HA has been commonly used as an injectable bioimplant for vocal fold augmentation/medialization, which involve injection into the deep layers of the vocal fold, for the treatment of insufficiency in vocal folds. To date, a few studies have reported on the viscoelasticity of injectable biomaterials in an in vitro comparison with that of human vocal fold mucosa.4-7 Some studies have shown that biomaterials with low viscoelasticity could render similar viscoelastic properties to that of vocal folds, when injected into in vivo rabbit vocal folds.8-10

However, discrepancy remains between studies that use different materials and concentrations of the materials, as well as a variety of injection sites. HA-based biomaterials usually create different structures depending on their structural modification and the degree of cross-linking. Therefore, knowledge of the different viscoelasticities of various biomaterials and their effects on the biomechanical properties of vocal folds is essential for successful phonosurgery.

In this study, we measured and compared the viscoelasticities of currently used HA-based biomaterials, which were differently structured, and investigated their influence on the viscoelastic properties of vocal folds after implantation into intact vocal folds in a rabbit model. Finally, we discuss how HA-based biomaterials affect viscoelasticity in in vivo vocal folds and its implications on phonosurgery of less stiff human vocal folds than that of rabbit vocal folds.

sec.title: Sample Biomaterials
sec.p: The following HA-based biomaterials were compared: Rofilan (Rofil Medical, the Netherlands), Restylane (Q-Med, Sweden), and dextran beads in HA (Reviderm, Rofil Medical, the Netherlands). All materials had similar molecular weights in vitro and the same HA concentration of 20 mg/mL in prepackaged syringes. These materials were manufactured with different cross-linking and stabilization processes. Restylane is a nonanimal stabilized material, which is stabilized with butanediol diglycidyl ether (BDDE). Rofilan is a double-cross-linked HA with the cross-linking reagents of vinyl sulfone and hydroxypropylmethyl cellulose. Reviderm is made with 25 mg/ml dextran microspheres in 20 mg/mL of HA.

sec.title: Animal Experiments
sec.p: For the experiments, 18 New Zealand white rabbits weighing 2.9 to 3.5 kg were used. Animal care and all experimental procedures were conducted in accordance with the Guide for Animal Experiments, and the experimental protocol was approved by the Institutional Animal Ethics Committee.

The animals were subcutaneously premedicated with 0.05 mg/kg of glycopyrrolate and 5 mg/kg of xylazine and then anesthetized with 15 mg/kg of zolazepam. The rabbits were divided into 3 groups of 6 animals according to the type of biomaterial to be injected. A volume of 50 µL of the respective biomaterial was injected into the deep layers of the vocal fold including the deep layer of lamina propria and/or muscle. Augmentation of the vocal folds was observed immediately after injection. We attempted to consistently inject all materials into the deep layers of the vocal fold using 25G long needles under direct vision with a pediatric laryngoscope (Karl Storz, Tuttlingen, Germany) and a surgical operating microscope (Carl Zeiss Ltd, Welwyn Garden City, UK). The contralateral vocal fold was used as a control.

sec.title: Rheometric Measurements
sec.p: Rheometric measurements were conducted at 2 months after the injection, considering poor durability of HA-based biomaterials. The convexity of the augmented vocal fold was observed to be maintained at 2 months after injection. Four larynges for each group were removed posteuthanasia, and the vocal fold without muscles and other supra- and subglottic connective tissues were meticulously dissected under magnified vision with a microscope. Each vocal fold sample was approximately 5 to 6 mm in length and 2 to 3 mm in depth. The dissected vocal folds were stored in normal saline at 37°C until viscoelastic measurements were undertaken.

A strain-controlled rheometer (ARES-LS, TA Instruments, New Castle, Delaware, USA) was used to measure the viscoelasticity of the biomaterial-injected vocal folds. The sample was placed between 2 parallel plates, of which the rotating lower plate included a temperature control system and induced a steady or oscillatory shear deformation on the samples. The opposing stationary upper plate was composed of measurement geometry and controlled the torque motor. The shear stress resulting from the steady or oscillatory shear deformation was measured by a piezoelectric force transducer of measurement geometry. The diameter of the upper plate was 3 mm for vocal fold tissue samples and 50 mm for biomaterials, and gap size was set to be 0.8 to 1.2 mm for full contact between the sample and the upper plate.

The oscillatory shear deformation was applied to the sample using the dynamic frequency sweep test at a frequency ranging from 0.01 to 15 Hz. The linear viscoelastic condition of the sample was measured by a series of dynamic strain sweep tests prior to a frequency sweep test. The temperature of the lower plate was set at 37°C, and the samples were humidified with a relative humidity of 100%.
In rheology, a purely elastic solid follows Hooke’s Law,

in which shear stress σ (force for unit area) and shear strain γ (relative deformation in shear) are related to a proportionality constant called the modulus G. A purely viscous liquid obeys Newton’s Law,

where shear stress and shear strain rate γ̇ (change in shear strain per unit time) are related to a proportionality constant called the viscosity η. In theory, because all matter has both viscous and elastic properties, the general linear constitutive equation is as shown below.
In dynamic mechanical tests, oscillatory deformation (strain) was applied to the sample, and the material response of the samples (stress) was measured. Strain under these conditions is defined as,
where ω is an angular frequency of oscillation.

Following the linear viscoelastic theory, materials respond at the same frequency as the input sine wave, but its amplitude is different and shifts over time. The change in amplitude is a measure of the material’s elastic modulus, and the temporal shift is a measure of the material’s viscous modulus. The standard nomenclature for the shear elastic modulus is G’ and for the viscous modulus is G”. In general, G’ represents the shear stiffness of the material and G” represents the fluidity of the material under shear deformation. For this study, we expressed G” as the dynamic viscosity using the equation shown below.
Both the viscous modulus and the elastic modulus vary as a function of frequency. Thus, data are typically collected over several frequency decades, as was done in the present investigation.

Contrarily, viscometry of HA-based biomaterials was performed by applying steady shear deformation at a shear rate ranging from 0.01 to 100 s-1. Steady shear deformation was used to test biomaterials because of their limited volume available for testing. Oscillatory measurement of dynamic viscosity involves a set of preliminary tests, which require additional loads of fresh samples. Conflict in comparing steady viscosity of biomaterials and dynamic viscosity of the vocal folds is able to be avoided by introducing an empirical rule named the Cox-Merz rule,11

In this study, TA Orchestrator software was used to calculate shear stress, shear strain, and shear strain rate. Viscoelastic parameters were calculated as functions of applied frequency according to the theory of linear viscoelasticity.12 The dependence of viscoelastic parameters on frequency can be parameterized by the power law,
where the coefficient a indicates the magnitude and the constant b indicates the slope on a log-log scale.13

sec.title: Histological and Ultrastructural Analysis
sec.p: Histological analysis was performed by a pathologist, who was blinded to the injection materials. Two months after the injection, 2 larynges for each group were harvested for histological and ultrastructural analysis. One larynx in each group was processed for light microscopy for assessment of injection location at the vocal folds and histological change of the injected biomaterials. Tissue samples from each group were embedded in paraffin block and the embedded tissue samples were cut at 4 µm on a microtome. Hematoxylin-eosin (H-E) staining was performed on 1 slide from each sample by the pathology department.

Another tissue sample in each group was fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde, flushed in 0.1 M phosphate buffer at pH 7.3, and added to 1% tannic acid to facilitate visualization of ECM for the transmission electronic microscopy (TEM). Thereafter, they were fragmented, hydrated, and embedded in an araldite resin block. The block was cut into 0.5 mm semifine slices along the coronal plane of the vocal fold. The slices were examined under light microscopy and then once again cut, this time into ultrafine slices, and were examined and photographed using a TEM magnifications (model EM 301, Philips AG, Holland), frame by frame, at increasing.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: The rheological data were analyzed utilizing a repeated measures analysis of covariance assuming a first-order autoregressive error structure within a subject using SAS PROC MIXED method (SAS Institute, Cary, North Carolina). Statistical significance was defined as a P value less than .05.

sec.title: HA-based Biomaterial Samples
sec.p: The shear viscosity (η) of biomaterial samples was measured as a function of frequency, and Figure 1 shows the results thereof on a log-log scale. All biomaterials demonstrated a similar η that decreased fast and monotonically as the shear rate increased, which is called shear thinning. After fitting the log-log curve to the power law, coefficient a and constant b of the biomaterials were calculated. The mean magnitude of η was also compared with those of calcium hydroxylapatite (Radiesse, BioForm Medical, San Mateo, California) in our additional measurement and human vocal fold tissue, measured in previous studies.6,12 All biomaterials showed similar slopes on the curve and a high R2, as an indication of a good fit. The mean magnitudes of η for all HA-based biomaterials were lower than that of Radiesse but higher than that of human vocal fold tissue (Table 1).

caption.p: The steady state viscosities (η) of the HA-based biomaterial samples and Radiesse, as well as dynamic viscosity (η′) of previously reported human vocal folds.12
Results of Curve Fitting by the Power Law for the Parametric Description of the Steady State Viscosity (η) of the Biomaterials

sec.title: Vocal Fold Tissue Samples
sec.p: Viscoelastic parameters, elastic moduli (G’), and viscous moduli (G”) of all 4 injected vocal fold tissue samples for each group and 9 of the 12 available samples of noninjected vocal folds were calculated as functions of applied frequency. The results of rheological analysis of G’ and G” of the injected vocal fold tissue samples were plotted on a log-log scale, shown in Figures 2 and 3. Tables 2 and 3 show the results of the parameterization of the G’ and G” curve. Power law fit of G’ and G” demonstrated similar slopes on the curve and R2 values greater than 0.7 for all conditions.

caption.p: Mean elastic modulus (G’) of the biomaterial-injected vocal folds and noninjected vocal folds.
Mean viscous modulus (G”) of the biomaterial-injected vocal folds and noninjected vocal folds.
Results of Curve Fitting by the Power Law for the Parametric Description of the Mean Elastic Modulus (G’) of Biomaterial-Injected Vocal Folds (n = 4) and Noninjected Vocal Folds (n = 9)
Results of Curve Fitting by the Power Law for the Parametric Description of the Mean Viscous Modulus (G”) of Biomaterial-Injected Vocal Folds (n = 4) and Noninjected Vocal Folds (n = 9)

sec.p: The mean magnitude of G’ of the injected samples gradually increased along with increased frequency. The values of coefficient a of all injected tissue samples were comparable, and no significant differences were found among all the injected tissue samples and controls (P = .65). The mean magnitude of G” of the samples steadily increased along with increased frequency. The values of coefficient a of all injected tissue samples were similar, and there were no significant differences among all the injected tissue samples and controls (P = .355).

sec.title: Histologic Findings
sec.p: Light microscopic images demonstrated that all materials were injected in the deep layer of the lamina propria and the medial parts of the thyroarytenoid muscle (Figure 4A). There was some foreign body reaction around the injection materials. TEM revealed HA particles evenly distributed in the regions of the lamina propria of rabbits and were abundantly present on the wavy collagenous fibers of the layer without any structural derangement (Figure 4B).

caption.p: (A) Representative hematoxylin-eosin staining of the biomaterial-injected vocal fold, showing that all materials were injected in the deep layer of the lamina propria and the medial parts of the thyroarytenoid muscle (LP, lamina propria; arrow: HA particles; bar = 100 µm, X200). (B) Transmission electron image depicting homogeneous distributions of HA particles of Rofilan in the regions of arranged collagenous fibers (H, HA particles; C, collagenous fibers; bar = 1µm, X3300).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: An ideal biomaterial for phonosurgery should preserve the body-cover structure of vocal folds and propagation of the normal mucosal wave during phonation. The native viscoelastic properties of vocal folds can change after injection of biomaterials, if the rheological characteristics of the biomaterials differ from those of the vocal folds. Furthermore, biomaterials may cause stiffness and more resistance to flow of the tissues, if the materials contribute to the synthesis of a new connective tissue or integrate within the tissues. Caton et al suggested that biomaterials with viscoelastic properties similar to human vocal fold mucosa appear to be appropriate for superficial injection into the vocal fold.6

There are a number of commercial HA-based products that are differently cross-linked or stabilized to withstand degradation in tissues.14,15 The viscoelastic properties of HA may vary with concentration, molecular weight, and cross-linking level. Chan et al found that HA at concentrations of 0.5% to 1% exhibited viscoelastic shear properties similar to those of the average human vocal fold mucosa.4 The difference in shear viscosity of the biomaterials is attributable to differences of cross-linking reagents and stabilizing process, although most HA-based biomaterials have similar molecular weights and concentrations.

In our study, 3 differently structured nonanimal stabilized HAs were tested. All biomaterials showed similar viscosities within a decade of magnitude. However, all materials were found to have higher shear viscosities (less fluid) in comparison to that of previously reported human vocal fold covers.6,12 Kimura et al, in an in vitro rheometric investigation of biomaterials, demonstrated that a cross-linked HA gel (Juvederm, Allergan Inc., Irvine, California) showed a significantly higher magnitude of dynamic viscosity than that of human vocal fold covers.7 Caton et al noted that the viscoelasticity of Restylane was higher than that of human vocal folds in their in vitro rheologic investigation.6

In this study, we presented data in terms of G’ and G” to compare viscoelastic properties between vocal folds injected with HA-based biomaterials and noninjected vocal folds. Chan and Titze presented calculations for phonation threshold pressure using these parameters, and Klemuk et al also used these variables in their investigation to measure injectable biomaterials up to 1400 Hz.16,17 The viscoelastic measures of normal vocal folds in the present study were validated by comparing to the values presented by Thibeault et al in their rheological investigation of rabbit vocal folds.18

The magnitudes of both G’ and G” of all biomaterial-injected vocal folds in the present study were nearly the same as those of noninjected vocal folds. Our data are comparable to a report by Dahlqvist et al,9 which found that vocal folds injected with Hylan B gel (Hylaform) and dextranomers in hyaluronan (Deflux) showed similar viscosities to control vocal folds. A report by Borzacchiello et al10 revealed that the viscosities of vocal folds injected with Restylane, Deflux, and Hylan B gel were similar to those of noninjected vocal folds, when measured 6 months after the injection. The shear thinning effects of HA-based biomaterials in this study were similar to previous reports. This implies vocal fold oscillation is maintained at high frequency when injected with these materials.4,8,19

Although our in vivo results suggested that the HA-based biomaterials could preserve the viscoelastic properties of the vocal folds in a rabbit model, the results may not be equally as applicable to human vocal folds. The viscoelasticity of human vocal folds is lower (less stiff and more fluid) than that of rabbit vocal folds, and also the microstructures of ECM surroundings are somewhat different from those in rabbits. Given that it may not be possible to evaluate the viscoelasticity of human vocal folds after injecting biomaterials in vivo, it is difficult to draw conclusions on whether HA-based biomaterials are suitable for rendering the natural viscoelasticity of human vocal folds. Therefore, caution is still advised against injecting an excessive amount of HA-based biomaterials into the superficial lamina propria in humans.

One limitation of this study is that viscoelasticity was measured at low frequencies ranging from 0.1 to 15 Hz; however, theoretical extrapolation to frequencies of the human phonation range (> 100 Hz) can be made based on a unique mathematical theory, which allows for the predictions of vocal fold shear properties at the frequency range of humans.5,20 The second limitation is that the 2-month observational period may not be sufficient to show in vivo changes. However, it may be difficult to observe rheological changes in vocal folds for a longer time because HA could be gradually absorbed over time.21 The third limitation to this study is that there may be inadequate statistical power to test the equivalence of parameters between groups because of small sample size. However, it was difficult to obtain a sufficient sample size for the study’s statistical calculations as the result of some practical issues, including animal ethics.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, 3 differently structured HA-based biomaterials showed similar shear viscosities, which were slightly higher than that of human vocal folds reported in previous studies. HA-based biomaterials were observed to be homogeneously distributed in the lamina propria and to preserve the viscoelastic properties of the vocal folds when they were injected into the deep layer of vocal fold in an in vivo rabbit model. However, caution is still advised against injecting an excessive amount of HA-based biomaterials into the superficial lamina propria in humans because HA-based biomaterials could render higher viscosities in the extracellular surroundings of human vocal folds, and further studies on the influence of the biomaterials on the viscoelasticity of human vocal folds in ECM surroundings are still needed.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Jeong-Seok Choi, data analysis, drafting and revising the article, final approval of the last version; Nahn Ju Kim, study design, acquisition of data, revising the article, final approval of the last version; Sarah Klemuk, study design, revising the article, final approval of the last version; Yun Ho Jang, acquisition of data, final approval of the last version; In Suh Park, data analysis, revising the article, final approval of the last version; Kyung Hyun Ahn, acquisition of data, final approval of the last version; Jae-Yol Lim, study design, data analysis, drafting and revising the article, final approval of the last version; Young-Mo Kim, study design, revising the article, final approval of the last version.
